note.body: I updated fetch_and_build.sh to check if AC_CONFIG_AUX_DIR is not found inside configure.ac, then it will add it to the configure.ac files. It builds nicely again!

target_title: Building libxml2/libxslt just stopped working (ltmain.sh missing) is it a race in libtool?

note.body:
Amazing, thank you so much! I would never have found this.

The latest successful Windows cross compile build on github was 2 days ago, and I can see now that there was in fact a warning on that build, that the ubuntu-latest build host would be upgradeed to 24.04. 
https://github.com/actions/runner-images/issues/10636

Perhaps AC_CONFIG_AUX_DIR([.]) is a good addition anyway, not just for me problem?

target_title: Building libxml2/libxslt just stopped working (ltmain.sh missing) is it a race in libtool?

note.body: Okay, I found that adding `AC_CONFIG_AUX_DIR([.])` after `AC_INIT` in libxml2's configure.ac helps.

target_title: Building libxml2/libxslt just stopped working (ltmain.sh missing) is it a race in libtool?

note.body:
I can reproduce the issue and I see:

```
.../xmq/3rdparty/libxml2-posix$ libtoolize -if
libtoolize: putting auxiliary files in '../..'.
libtoolize: copying file '../../ltmain.sh'
```

But the files should be put in `.`. Apparently, libtoolize thinks `../..` (the xmq directory) is the autoconf root directory and installs its files there. Looking at the [code here](https://github.com/autotools-mirror/libtool/blob/5586070a7199737861f4647c1dd81cd028435b76/libtoolize.in#L1591), libtoolize finds `../../install.sh` in the xmq directory because its run (by autoreconf) before libxml2's install.sh is installed by automake.

I have no idea when or how this changed, but I can't see how this could be fixed in libxml2.

target_title: Building libxml2/libxslt just stopped working (ltmain.sh missing) is it a race in libtool?
build: adjust build rules for Android

note.body:
> We use `target_link_libraries(LibXml2 PRIVATE Threads::Threads)`, so the flags shouldn't be part of the link interface.

Maybe I was wrong here, but if `-pthread` works when building libxml2, why does it cause problems for downstream code?

target_title: build: adjust build rules for Android

note.body:
> The issue is that when built statically, the library has `-pthread` in the interface flags.

We use `target_link_libraries(LibXml2 PRIVATE Threads::Threads)`, so the flags shouldn't be part of the link interface.

> On Android, the pthread library is part of the C library and does not need to be linked in as it is always implicitly available.

This isn't unusual. There are several other platforms like macOS or modern glibc where the pthread functions are built in.

target_title: build: adjust build rules for Android

note.body: Setting that to `NO` would be possible, but that doesn't help in this case. The issue is that when built statically, the library has `-pthread` in the interface flags. If that is mixed with another language (Swift), the propagation of the flags is a problem. On Android, the pthread library is part of the C library and does not need to be linked in as it is always implicitly available.
No, internal functions are allowed to have stricter preconditions.

> This is an internal function which is never called with a `SIZE_MAX` argument.

Should still probably fix it though, right?
We can file a rejection request with MITRE: https://cveform.mitre.org/

target_title: build: adjust build rules for Android

note.body:
As far as I can tell, libxml2 uses the officially documented way to detect thread support with CMake. I wouldn't want to add a hack that changes undocumented internal CMake variables without explanation.

Can you explain what exactly is going wrong? Which command receives the `-pthread` flag wrongly and why? I simply can't see how libxml2 is at fault here.

There's also a `THREADS_PREFER_PTHREAD_FLAG` option which is recommended but which libxml2 does not set. But it seems even less helpful to set this option.

This is an internal function which is never called with a `SIZE_MAX` argument.

This is not a security issue. Please don't request CVE IDs before getting in touch with maintainers.

target_title: build: adjust build rules for Android

note.body: How is it an issue in CMake? The use of `-pthread` is embedded into the generated config for libxml2. The change here just avoids doing that.
I think it's an issue in PHP, but similar leaks in libxml2 were fixed here: https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/libxml2/-/commit/b3871dd138ad68a22ef315809bbe4b071090711b

> I looked through the patches and the only one that might be of interest to you is at https://github.com/microsoft/vcpkg/blob/3b57fb2e1ff55613db14d2aaf0a30529289c7050/ports/libxml2/fix_cmakelist.patch#L18-L22 .

`XML_LIBS` contains GCC-style compiler flags, so I'm not sure why the check is for `MSVC`. Something like `WIN32 AND NOT MINGW` might make more sense.

target_title: build: adjust build rules for Android

note.body: If you are using this package with a mixed language project (e.g. Swift), you end up passing `-pthread` which is not a valid flag there.

Thanks @nwellnhof ! The PR over in GitHub is updated based on your feedback.

Not sure how familiar you are with `vcpkg` but one thing it does do is patch the repository to make things abide by its conventions but also sometimes fix build breakages. You can see the patches for `libxml2` at https://github.com/microsoft/vcpkg/tree/master/ports/libxml2 . I looked through the patches and the only one that might be of interest to you is at https://github.com/microsoft/vcpkg/blob/3b57fb2e1ff55613db14d2aaf0a30529289c7050/ports/libxml2/fix_cmakelist.patch#L18-L22 .

Some dependent projects in `vcpkg` failed to build on Windows due to the pkgconfig file using `-lxml2` instead of `-llibxml2` which is set by `XML_LIBS`. If you want to take that portion of the patch feel free, or if there's a better way to approach it have at it.

Thanks again!

> First I saw there were a few `set`s around all the `option`s and wasn't sure if those are things that should be exposed. The listing of them is `LIBXML2_WITH_AUTOMATA`, `LIBXML2_WITH_EXPR`, and `LIBXML2_WITH_UNICODE`.

These options were removed and have no effect. I just deleted the remaining bits from CMake here: 0c772751

> Second I also wasn't sure exactly what the minimum feature set in `libxml2` that was required to do `libxslt`. I was able to build by turning on `LIBXML2_WITH_HTML`, `LIBXML2_WITH_OUTPUT`, `LIBXML2_WITH_TREE` and `LIBXML2_WITH_XPATH`.

Yes, this should be the set of required features for libxslt. Note that `LIBXML2_WITH_TREE` will be removed in 2.14. This flag should always be enabled.

note.body: We're dealing with UTF-8 chars here and `len` can only increase by a maximum of four bytes in each iteration. So when `memcpy` is called, the maximum value for `len` is `XML_MAX_NAMELEN - 1 + 4` which is two bytes smaller than `sizeof(buf)`.

target_title: `warning: unknown warning group '-Wcast-function-type'` from old AppleClang

note.body:
For Clang & AppleClang, I would suggest this construct:

```c
#if defined(__clang__) && defined(__has_warning)
  #if __has_warning("-Wcast-function-type")
    #pragma clang diagnostic push
    #pragma clang diagnostic ignored "-Wcast-function-type"
  #endif
#endif
```

This way there's no messing with versions or variants of Clang.

note.body: Can you submit a merge request?
There's no official release with a fix yet. Does the following commit (on the 2.13 branch) work for you: https://gitlab.gnome.org/nwellnhof/libxml2/-/commit/2617138d924e19211b530373162d93b8edc54eb8
Thanks @nwellnhof! I've tried your patch with Autotools, CMake and Meson. I can confirm that they all worked with ICU enabled. Let me close this MR in favour of your commit.

Thanks for the report!

I think we don't have to check for `icu-i18n` at all, only for `icu-uc`. Does this commit work for you: https://gitlab.gnome.org/nwellnhof/libxml2/-/commit/b57e022d75425ef8b617a1c3153198ee0a941da8

>According to the clang documentation, the `unsigned-shift-base` sanitizer [is available since version 12](https://releases.llvm.org/12.0.1/tools/clang/docs/UndefinedBehaviorSanitizer.html#available-checks).

Correct. But of course that's open source Clang 12, not AppleClang 12. The version numbers are not in-sync.

>I'm aware of that but I don't think Apple documents this anywhere.

Apple's docs are well-known for their incompleteness. :(

Where I work we have a bot running each of macOS 10.10 through 15.x, each with the newest Xcode possible for that version of macOS.  AppleClang 12 does not support `unsigned-shift-base`.  AppleClang 13 does.

You can detect AppleClang by by the presence of the `__apple_build_version__` macro, something like:

`#if defined(__apple_build_version__) && (__apple_build_version__ >= 13000000)`

Thanks for your speedy reply.

I've just tried master and indeed it builds on the same Mac.  And I double checked the v2.13.4 tag and indeed it does *not* build.

Is there any release with this fixed?

If not, perhaps my suggested hack would be appropriate for your stable branch?

target_title: Please expose parseBalancedChunk in python bindings

note.body:
The Python bindings require manual memory management, making anything that uses them memory-unsafe. There are better alternatives like lxml.

Only the following Debian packages depend on them:

- daps (seems to be an error)
- itstool
- munin-libvirt-plugins
- python3-dmidecode
- virtinst
- xgridfit (Version 3 seems to have switched to lxml)

target_title: Please expose parseBalancedChunk in python bindings

note.body: Why do you consider the Python bindings deprecated? (I might be interested in doing something about that.)

target_title: meson: Look for ICU with CMake too

note.body: any news on this MR ?

> Where you wrote `#if __clang_major__ >= 12` maybe you meant `>`, not `>=`?

According to the clang documentation, the `unsigned-shift-base` sanitizer [is available since version 12](https://releases.llvm.org/12.0.1/tools/clang/docs/UndefinedBehaviorSanitizer.html#available-checks).

> Or maybe this is because you didn't know that Apple's fork of Clang does not always align in version numbers with the open source Clang.

I'm aware of that but I don't think Apple documents this anywhere.

We already stopped checking for headers and symbols separately in the master branch and now use `check_symbol_exists` for CMake. This should avoid compilation failures if the symbol is detected but the header isn't.

In fact it's not quite a complete fix...

I still see:

```
libxml2/vtklibxml2/dict.c:464:1: warning: unknown sanitizer 'unsigned-shift-base' ignored [-Wunknown-sanitizers]
ATTRIBUTE_NO_SANITIZE_INTEGER
^
libxml2/vtklibxml2/libxml.h:61:29: note: expanded from macro 'ATTRIBUTE_NO_SANITIZE_INTEGER'
      ATTRIBUTE_NO_SANITIZE("unsigned-shift-base")
                            ^
```

With Xcode 12.4 on macOS 10.15 where clang is:

```
xcrun clang --version
Apple clang version 12.0.0 (clang-1200.0.32.29)
```

Where you wrote `#if __clang_major__ >= 12`  maybe you meant `>`, not `>=`?

Or maybe this is because you didn't know that Apple's fork of Clang does not always align in version numbers with the open source Clang.  `>= 12` may be correct for open source Clang, but it is clearly not for AppleClang.

target_title: Is the `fd` in `xmlNanoHTTPFetch` correct when `filename` is “-”?

note.body:
> It could be beneficial to encourage projects that rely on libxml2 to stop using these APIs now.

All deprecated APIs should already generate deprecation warnings when used. But it's not only about API symbols but library features like HTTP or compression support. These features don't require special parser options, so it's hard to detect which projects depend on them.

I'm conducting this round of rebuild tests to gain insight into the effects of eliminating the legacy APIs, and I'll keep `--with-legacy` in the official Debian packages as supposed to.

If I understand correctly, you are planning to deprecate these APIs with the goal of removing them eventually. It could be beneficial to encourage projects that rely on libxml2 to stop using these APIs now. Then distros will need another SONAME bump to stop building libxml2 using `--with-legacy`.

target_title: URI wrong for fully qualified path on Windows

note.body:
For build failures related to the 2.12 release, see #642.

> without `--with-legacy`

Then you should add `--with-http` and probably `--with-zlib` and `--with-lzma` as well. But I really recommend the `--with-legacy` option.

I've started a test rebuild of all libxml2's reverse dependencies in Debian unstable, using libxml2 2.13.3 (without `--with-legacy`, but still have `--with-history --with-ftp --with-xptr-loc`).

There are 752 source packages at first glance and it may take some time to finish. It's showing 37 failures out of 223 tried ones as of writing this comment. I'll report back with accurate numbers and corresponding logs when the rebuild has completed.

note.body:
My bad, I think I shuffled everything in my mind, and missed the E in XXE 😅

Indeed, the issue in my head was the entity expansion in namespaces, but, indeed, since it's only internal ones and the protection against loops in expansion and the expansion size constraint are present, there are, indeed, no vulnerabilities.

My bad. And I'm sorry to have wasted your time. I will have to try harder 😅

I close this issue, but, if you need any additional information, or if I really find something, do not hesitate to reopen it :)

Have a great day!

target_title: Billion laughs attack executed despite libxml2 protection
Billion laughs attack executed despite libxml2 protection

note.body: Also note that since f506ec66, entities in namespace declarations are always expanded. This is by design and harmless. Protection against billion laugh attacks is always enabled.

push_data.commit_title: python/tests: fix typos

target_title: Billion laughs attack executed despite libxml2 protection

note.body:
I don't understand the report. You seem to mix up XXE and billion laugh attacks.

The `XML_PARSE_NO_XXE` option only disables loading of *external* entities. Your example contains an internal entity, so everything works as designed.

Billion laugh attacks are a separate issue but your example does not demonstrate a vulnerability. What makes you think that the expansion of a single internal entity is a security issue?

target_title: Billion laughs attack executed despite libxml2 protection
xmllint rejects XSD schema as "not determinist" when it has an <any> element

note.body:
Thanks for the hint. Indeed, with Xerces-J 2.12.2 (`xml-schema-1.1` variant) I get an error when using XML Schema 1.0:
```
$ java -classpath xercesSamples.jar:xercesImpl.jar:org.eclipse.wst.xml.xpath2.processor_1.2.1.jar \
       jaxp.SourceValidator -f -a its.xsd -i docbook4.its
[Error] its.xsd:31:33: cos-nonambig: "http://www.w3.org/2005/11/its":translateRule and WC["http://www.w3.org/2005/11/its","http://itstool.org/extensions/"] (or elements from their substitution group) violate "Unique Particle Attribution". During validation against this schema, ambiguity would be created for those two particles.
docbook4.its: 6 ms
```
and no error when using XML Schema 1.1:
```
$ java -classpath xercesSamples.jar:xercesImpl.jar:org.eclipse.wst.xml.xpath2.processor_1.2.1.jar \
       jaxp.SourceValidator -xsd11 -f -a its.xsd -i docbook4.its
docbook4.its: 10 ms
```
This matches what I read in https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unique_Particle_Attribution and https://stackoverflow.com/questions/17580614/ .

You can transform this issue into a wishlist item for XML Schema 1.1 support.

target_title: xmllint rejects XSD schema as "not determinist" when it has an <any> element

note.body:
From the 2.12.0 release notes:

> Several bugs in the regex determinism checks were fixed. Invalid XML
Schemas which previous versions erroneously accepted will now be
rejected.

I'm not an expert but it seems that the `<any>` element violates the Unique Particle Attribution rule. You should check what better XSD software like Xerces says about your schema.

There was some project in gnome namespace. I can't recall which. I think they ported away from deprecated API after I filed a bug but it was too close to ABI freeze to risk removing this stuff. Especially since there was no soname change. We can remove the API in this cycle which is frozen next August. I can dig it up later if there's interest.

I decided to bump the soname for the 2.14 release. The `--with-legacy` option will remain to help with gradually phasing out features like the HTTP client.

> there were still some projects which depended on this "legacy" API and now we are stuck with it

Which projects and which part of the API exactly?

Speaking with flatpak base runtime maintainer hat on the point when I found this ticket, there were still some projects which depended on this "legacy" API and now we are stuck with it until next allowed ABI break window. I'm worried though that unless soname is changed, we are stuck with the old ABI _forever_ with no clean path forward.

> the removal of symbols from the default configuration. This can be easily fixed by adding `--with-legacy`.

Oh, i totally missed the `--with-legacy` option. That is great, thanks! But it would be good if SO version should be bumped when `--with-legacy` is omitted then. Maybe even rename the option to `--with-abi-version=2` and let `--with-abi-version=3` be the default? That way packagers have a clean way to move to the new ABI.

I am in the process of making a rebuild of the world for alpine 3.21, so This would be a perfect time for me to switch to new ABI - if there was a clean way to do so.

> potential incompatibilities arising from changes to public structs. It's the latter that I meant in my "hypothetical" comment.

Well, this is computers. Anything that *can* go wrong *will* go wrong. And breakages due to silent changes in in public structs will be very difficult to debug, so it would be very appreciated if those also could go with a new SONAME, so we can detect that a rebuild is needed early.

target_title: xmllint rejects XSD schema as "not determinist" when it has an <any> element

note.body: There are two separate issues here. One is the removal of symbols from the default configuration. This can be easily fixed by adding `--with-legacy`. The other issue is potential incompatibilities arising from changes to public structs. It's the latter that I meant in my "hypothetical" comment.

@ncopa it was known since creation of this issue that this is not hypothetical issue but cause of real breakage. This was reported originally by Debian maintainer for exactly same reason as you chimed in.

Things will only get less maintainable for anyone including libxml2 maintainers until ABI policy is fixed.

push_data.commit_title: Update NEWS

note.body:
This is breaking peoples pipelines using `alpine:edge` as we speak.

I'm all for removing code, but please bump the SO version if you do, so we can pick it up and know what to rebuild before it hits the users.

Hi, Alpine Linux maintainer here.

We now have Alpine Linux packages broken due to lack of rebuilding when needed. It was not possible for us to pick up that a rebuild was needed due to SONAME didn't change. This is absolutely not a hypothetical problem.

```
$ ldd libgsf
/lib/ld-musl-x86_64.so.1: cannot load libgsf: No such file or directory
ncopa-desktop:~/aports/main (master)$ ldd /usr/lib/libgsf-1.so.114
	/lib/ld-musl-x86_64.so.1 (0x7f1440219000)
	libgio-2.0.so.0 => /usr/lib/libgio-2.0.so.0 (0x7f143fff1000)
	libgobject-2.0.so.0 => /usr/lib/libgobject-2.0.so.0 (0x7f143ff90000)
	libglib-2.0.so.0 => /usr/lib/libglib-2.0.so.0 (0x7f143fe3e000)
	libintl.so.8 => /usr/lib/libintl.so.8 (0x7f143fe2c000)
	libxml2.so.2 => /usr/lib/libxml2.so.2 (0x7f143fd2b000)
	libz.so.1 => /usr/lib/libz.so.1 (0x7f143fd10000)
	libbz2.so.1 => /usr/lib/libbz2.so.1 (0x7f143fcfd000)
	libc.musl-x86_64.so.1 => /lib/ld-musl-x86_64.so.1 (0x7f1440219000)
	libgmodule-2.0.so.0 => /usr/lib/libgmodule-2.0.so.0 (0x7f143fcf6000)
	libmount.so.1 => /usr/lib/libmount.so.1 (0x7f143fcb4000)
	libffi.so.8 => /usr/lib/libffi.so.8 (0x7f143fcaa000)
	libpcre2-8.so.0 => /usr/lib/libpcre2-8.so.0 (0x7f143fbff000)
	liblzma.so.5 => /usr/lib/liblzma.so.5 (0x7f143fbc7000)
	libblkid.so.1 => /usr/lib/libblkid.so.1 (0x7f143fb96000)
	libeconf.so.0 => /usr/lib/libeconf.so.0 (0x7f143fb8a000)
Error relocating /usr/lib/libgsf-1.so.114: xmlNanoHTTPClose: symbol not found
Error relocating /usr/lib/libgsf-1.so.114: xmlNanoHTTPRead: symbol not found
Error relocating /usr/lib/libgsf-1.so.114: xmlNanoHTTPOpen: symbol not found
Error relocating /usr/lib/libgsf-1.so.114: xmlNanoHTTPContentLength: symbol not found
```

> I think most users prefer the SONAME to be stable even if there are slight ABI/API changes.

I think most users prefer that their packages works.

Silently breaking ABI is the packagers maintainers worst nightmare.

Please please please help us maintainers by follow the SONAME conventions!

Please!

note.body: I've merged the Nokogiri branch into main. 🙌

The following set of commits makes the HTML parser adhere to the HTML5 tokenization rules:

- dcb2abb2f html: Parse tag and attribute names according to HTML5
- 939b53ee1 html: Stop skipping tag content
- f2272c231 html: Handle unexpected-solidus-in-tag according to HTML5
- a80f8b64a html: Allow attributes in end tags
- 72e29f9a3 html: Fix quadratic behavior in push parser
- 637215a4d html: Always terminate doctype declarations on '>'
- dc2d49831 html: Rework htmlLookupSequence
- d5cd0f07f html: Prefer SKIP(1) over NEXT in HTML parser
- 595117923 html: Parse named character references according to HTML5
- f9ed30e97 html: HTML5 character data states
- e1834745e html: Add character data tests
- ccb61f599 html: Remove duplicate calls to htmlAutoClose
- 0d324bde3 html: Simplify node info accounting
- 86d6b9b05 html: Deduplicate some code
- 844401757 html: Add missing calls to htmlCheckParagraph()
- 3adb396d8 html: Parse bogus comments instead of ignoring them
- 341dc78f2 html: Deduplicate code in htmlCurrentChar
- 17da54c52 html: Normalize newlines
- e062a4a9b html: Add HTML5 parser option
- 4eeac3094 html: Start to fix EOF and U+0000 handling
- a6955c13c html: Parse numeric character references according to HTML5
- 9678163f5 html: Don't check for valid XML characters
- 6edf1a645 html: Fix DOCTYPE parsing
- bca648547 html: Allow U+000C FORM FEED as whitespace
- 24a09033c html: Fix bogus end tags
- 17e56ac54 html: Fix parsing of end tags
- b19d35397 html: Fix EOF handling in comments
- 27752f75c html: Fix EOF handling in start tags

The tokenizer is now tested against the html5lib test suite:

- c6af10172 html: Test tokenizer against html5lib test suite

Several other improvements and related fixes:

- e179f3ec0 html: Stop reporting syntax errors
- 9f04cce69 html: Remove unused or useless return codes
- 42c3823df html: Update comment
- 462bf0b7a html: Rework options
- be874d783 html: Ignore unexpected DOCTYPE declarations
- 575be6c1f html: Fix line numbers with CRs
- 76cc63942 test: Fix XML_PARSE_HTML constant
- 0ce7bfe55 html: Try to avoid passing XML options to HTML parser
- 0144f662d html: Remove obsolete code
- 188cad68a html: Remove obsolete content model
- 6040785ac html: Deprecate AutoClose API
- c34d0ae9c html: Deprecate htmlIsBooleanAttr
- 440bd64c6 html: Optimize htmlParseHTMLName
- f77ec16db html: Optimize htmlParseCharData
- e84065541 html: Rewrite parsing of most data
- c32397d51 html: Improve character class macros
- 24a6149fc html: Make sure that character data mode is reset
- 0bc4608c5 html: Use hash table to check for duplicate attributes
- 207999793 html: Handle numeric character references directly
- 225ed7073 html: Accelerate htmlParseCharData
- 3ac214f01 xmllint: Support --html --sax
- a4c16a140 xmllint: Improve --memory and --testIO options

target_title: Quadratic behavior in HTML push parser with unquoted attribute values

note.body:
"auto" should be the same as "pkg-config" on Linux. Running `pkg-config --cflags libxml-2.0` should print the required compiler flags which the build system should pick up.

    $ pkg-config --cflags libxml-2.0
    -I/usr/include/libxml2

If we added a symlink in /usr/include, this would end up on the majority of Linux systems. Such hacks do not seem common practice and are probably frowned upon by distro maintainers.

Even if I specify the dependency detection method as 'pkg-config' (instead of auto), dependency libxml-2.0 is found, but there is still a fatal error: 'libxml/parser.h' file not found.

Installing this symlink here can cause some problems? If not, why not add it? :smiley:

target_title: Integrate downstream test suites into CI

note.body: @nwellnhof should be green now. Unless you're doing more work on that branch I will merge the Nokogiri branch into `main`, let me know!
This is not a support or discussion forum. Please only use the issue tracker for bug reports.

This shouldn't be an issue if you use pkg-config to detect libxml2.

Maybe we should simply start to install the headers in `$(includedir)/libxml`, but this would probably break things for some users.
